ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned an enormous amount about tensions over language and translation in Renaissance Europe, from questions of Latin's fixity or fluidity, questions of inborn qualities or styles in ancient languages, to the question of whether the past is close to us or far away which motivates so much Renaissance thinking. I think I gained a lot of insight into what motivates translation as an enterprise, and I gained skills I never knew I had in doing my own translations.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: I think the strengths of this course were in how it was at once broad and focused, covering a couple hundred years of writing but always with a pointed focus on our question of translation. It opened so many doors and told a number of different stories without expecting expertise in every area, because all the students came with different interests and backgrounds. I think this responsiveness to student interest also made the course very successful.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes yes yes take the class Professor Tylus is a genius

Absolutely! I think anyone with any interest in translation or in the Renaissance would enjoy this course, and Jane did such a wonderful job responding the diversity of interests in the class that I would recommend it to anyone.
